ygData.subject: Re: Crossover Operator, Bucklands Windows NEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: I do not have specific knowledge of all the variants of NEAT crossover operators, so it is definitely possible that Mat Buckland s works slightly differently

Subject: Re: Crossover Operator, Bucklands Windows NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=taSvsOw_AieFqbiIH2msPfAIUPdwr5hD9rPtAwTbHPgROpHgQiWU

I do not have specific knowledge of all the variants of NEAT crossover op=
erators, so it is definitely possible that Mat Buckland's works slightly di=
fferently than the one we described in our publication.  Ultimately I do no=
t think it is essential that crossover operators are strictly one way or an=
other because the general alignment provided by the historical markings is =
the most important part.  Some techniques try to keep the genomes short by =
taking into account which parent is most fit or most short when considering=
 disjoint genes, but I do not think it will make a big performance differen=
t either way, though with some variants you might notice a bit more bloat o=
ver time than with others.

Indeed crossover is usually applied only to ind=
ividuals in the same species.  My version of NEAT allows some inter-species=
 mating that is controlled with an inter-species mating rate, and others mi=
ght have something similar.  In general, you do not want too much mating be=
tween different species because even if you know how to align the genomes, =
they are often going to be totally incompatible, like trying to mate a bird=
 with a pig and hoping for a flying pig.  Once genomes are sufficiently dif=
ferentiated, even the most parsimonious combination is likely nonfunctional=
 (e.g. because pig subsystems do not integrate with bird subsystems).

On t=
he other hand, at the fringes of species, i.e. when the genomes are differe=
ntiated but not too differentiated, combination can still work and be quite=
 interesting, like a lion mating with a tiger (which is possible in nature)=
.   In versions of NEAT with a dynamic compatibility threshold (which means=
 the criteria for being considered in the same species gradually change ove=
r generations), it is as if some species steal the offspring of other speci=
es that are right in that borderland where they are not too differentiated.=
  So that can lead to something similar to inter-species mating.

ken

--- =
In neat@yahoogroups.com, "rvonwahlde" <rvonwahlde@...> wrote:
>
> As best a=
s I can determine, the Crossover operator in Buckland's Windows NEAT does n=
ot function quite like that described in Stanley's "Efficient Evolution of =
Neural Networks through Complexification" report.  
> 
> I created two pare=
nt genomes like those in Figure 3.3.  Buckland's code does not allow "each =
disjoint and excess gene" to be "inherited from either parent randomly" eve=
n when they have equal fitnesses. For equal fitnesses it can only inherit t=
hem from the shorter genome (Parent 1) otherwise it will inherit only from =
the fitter genome.  Thus one could never get the child pictured in Figure 3=
.3.
> 
> Has anyone made a similar conclusion or have I perhaps coded Buckl=
and's program incorrectly.  I am making a version of NEAT in Labview using =
Buckland's code and conventions as a guide. 
> 
> Also, why is the Crossove=
r only applied to members within the same species?  Doesn't the speciation =
process tend to group members with the same topology?  Would cross-species =
crossovers allow for new hybrids to arise?
>
